text.p: Following are some of the top headlines in leading Italian newspapers.

* Foreign minister Lamberto Dini said he agreed with France's stand on European economic and monetary union and its emphasis on the need to create new jobs. Dini also stressed the important role of politics in EMU, adding that a stability pact for Europe's planned single currency could be reached in time for next week's European Union summit in Amsterdam or immediately after it (all).

* Massimo D'Alema, the head of Italian bicameral commission looking into much-needed contitutional reforms, said that political parties had lodged so many amendments to key proposals that voting on them all would be impossible (all).
* The transport committee of the lower house of parliament rejected the Italian government's three-year economic programme (DPEF) in a vote without repercussions for the package as a whole (all).
* A study by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) showed Italy will have a deficit/GDP ratio of 3.2 percent in 1997 and 3.8 percent in 1998 (all).
* Tomasi Tommasi di Vignano, managing director of Italian state telecommunications giant Stet, said the group is aiming for an alliance with AT&T Corp by the end of the year (all).

* The Italian Treasury said control of banking group Banco di Napoli officially passed to insurance company INA and bank BNL. Newly formed Banco di Napoli Holiding Spa, which is 51 percent owned by INA and 49 percent by Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, took over a 60 percent stake sold by the Treasury as part of a project to rescue the southern Italian bank (all).
* Insurance group RAS said that premium income in the first five months of 1997 rose more than seven percent, with genaral premiums up five percent and life premiums rising 12 percent (all).
** Reuters has not verified these stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
